title: Grandma & Grandad Haywood's Splitscreen 1963 Devon Caravette

posts.content:
1963 Devon Caravette 315 KNP (not on the DVLA!)

I have asked Dave Haywood's permission to reveal the slides for the DICS to see and to use these as reference pictures/ discussion items.
Dave anything you wish me to EDIT....shout!

Enjoy these timewarp pictures!

David Haywood had heard before from several family members that his Grandad had been a Devon Caravette owner in the 60s but had never heard any specifc details from his Grandad. At a recent family re-union. a chance conversation with his Aunt revealed that she had some slides showing the Camper, she could transfer the slides onto the computer and would send them to him.....

When I was talking to Dave on line about my 1964 Devon Caravette, Dave relayed the brief details of the conversation and that he had received the images and he sent them for dating......
The pictures show his Grandad, Grandma, Father and Aunty!

The VW splitscreen body is definately interesting from the changeover period....
Tin top
Bullet Indicators
Inward facing vents
Narrow hatch ***EDIT It is not a wide hatch EDIT***
Shallow dog's legs
Lipped Rear wheel arches
Euro rear lights
Slash cut bumper
Sealing wax Red & Beige Grey with Basalt Grey interior... exactly like my March 1962 Devonette

So 1962/3 - which was it? ... The Devon interior gave some misleading clues

Definately a 1962 MY interior...but maybe carried over to July 1963/ August 1963

BUT surprising with a *****EDIT Light Grey EDIT***** (Agreed Maddison just like my darker Grey interior....but it does look bluey Turquoise) Duracour interior!...

I have asked Dave's permission to reveal the slides to the DICS for them to use these as reference pictures/ discussion items.

Enjoy these timewarp pictures!

315 KNP - on holiday on the "wrong side of the road" in Austria venturing above the snow line




The registration 315 KNP is from Worcstershire in a series dating from April 1963 which confirms our initial dating of the features of the VW Microbus to changeover 1962/3
Interesting roof rack with rubber feet on the roof panel...
Like monkey knuts

Camping cooking outdoors
Narrow hatch...
Side of rear hatch in line with side of the engine lid...



1962 Devon Caravette interior with
"elusive green cooker"
Gas bottle in the engine bay with hose evident coming out of the engine lid
Flushmount fittings on the front of the tall cupboard face
Red water bottle - did it have a water tank?
Large Table outside
Cut away interior panel for cutlery holder
Narrow hatch rear drawers
Exterior aerial on gutter!


Grandma & Grandad in bed with 1962/3 curtains

Never seen that pattern before!
No rear cupboards



No idea what is on the floor!





But can see the day awning through the windows of the bus!

Awning has side curtains



Love the circular Ever Ready battery powered gas lighter

Caravette Badge on the front door



Gas pipe from cooker leading to gas valve inside on front of cooker cupboard

1962 Table mounting & easco



Black capped screws holding mounting panel onto long side
Easco light on wall

Lots of detail for DICS...

Thanks to David Haywood.
You can even see the finger print on the slide!
That's a pretty cool road trip, looks like good times

amazing pics and great detail…especially the curtains
fantasitc to see a devon in use at the time

and totally agree…62/63 model
oh…and the duracour looks like the light grey to me, exactly what you would expect in a red bus

presses like button
What about submitting a copy to Mike the Mag

Now that is a good idea!
Would have to ask Dave though!

Not my call...
We had lots of fun looking at the features...
I thought the duracour was blueish but I can see it was light grey..
A real late change over bus,,,

So Dave what about it?

The red water bottle is Devon supplied BTW I have a yellow one somewhere
also not the shaving mirror bracket by the easicool, I've seen it there before on a few busses...but also note no shaving bracket on the cargo doors....interesting

No I believe the flushmount fitting on the front cupboard are to mount the cooker there?
I have seen these pair of flushmount fittings there and they line up with the cut out holes on the back of the "elusive" green cooker so you can cook inside/make tea easily when the doors are shut!

Anyone?

That was my understanding of the flushmounts too. My wardrobe doesn't have them but I have a spare wardrobe lower panel with them on and yes they fit the cooker. Steve's (Etiennevert) bus has them too.
I can't tell you how the cooker stays up - I presume it sits on the edge of the seat above the easicool?

No rear cupboard on Granny's side but I would expect one on Grandpa's side? - I can't see in through the windows properly on the other photos though.

Lovely slides thanks for sharing.

We have had this conversation before...the 62 Caravette pictures I shared (with the sink so we could discuss sink door changes. .. SAD....do not have a cupboard there)....so I think this is just on the changeover before/ after they were introduced. I believe the Devonette had a full height cheapo sliding door cupboard and corner one on other side.
Even the 66 had pairs a slider full height cupboard and a crockery cupboard.

62 Caravette



You showed it for the sink change phases..
Maddisons 64MY interior from the early 64 period has the double cupboards...
The 63 Devonette brochure picture I posted showed a cupboard in the rear driver side corner on an angle and a sliding drop down cupboard in the rear on the passenger side...

So for me after 1958 it was none or two...and so for me none...

We'll never know unless we get a concensus view from Dave's Dad and Aunty...

But they are excellent period shots are they not..
I am waiting for some 8mm film to digitise from the PO of my 62 Devonette..
I am gently coaxing but may not get..

The brackets on the front of the wardrobe were for the cooker to be mounted inside on days when you did not want to put up the awning but needed to cook. We used to do it a lot on various trips. I only know this because we have had our 63 Devon since 64.
Those pictures are fantastic.

Caravette...I presume...
still looking for Devonette info and pictures...
